questions.question: In the given acid-base nomogram diagram, areas marked A and D indicated which of the following conditions?

options.A: Chronic respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis
options.B: Acute metabolic alkalosis, acute respiratory acidosis
options.C: Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis
options.D: Acute respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis Explanation: A - Acute respiratory acidosis occurs when there is an increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO 2 ) in the blood due to inadequate ventilation. This can be caused by conditions such as pneumonia, pulmonary edema, or airway obstruction. D - Acute respiratory alkalosis occurs when there is a decrease in PaCO 2 in the blood due to excessive ventilation. It can be caused by hyperventilation due to anxiety, fever, or high altitude. Acid-base disorders Simple acid-base disorders and their compensatory mechanisms: Primary respiratory disturbances (changes in PaCO I ) lead to metabolic compensation (changes in [HCO II ] ). Primary metabolic disturbances (changes in [HCO II ] ) lead to respiratory compensation (changes in PaCO I ). Compensation moves pH toward normal , but typically does not fully correct it, except for chronic respiratory alkalosis , which may restore normal pH. Metabolic acidosis (e.g., from ketoacidosis or lactic acidosis) lowers [HCO II ] and extracellular pH , triggers

questions.question: Identify the urinary crystal shown below:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Calcium oxalate Explanation: The given image showing an envelope or dumbbell shape under the microscope is characteristic of calcium oxalate crystals. Types of Renal Stones: Stone type Image Composition X-ray, CT Findings Urine crystal shape Key features Calcium oxalate Calcium oxalate Radiopaque Hyperdense Envelope/ dumbbell shaped Most common (80%) Risk factors: Ethylene glycol ingestion Seen in acidic urine Calcium phosphate (Option B) Calcium phosphate Radiopaque Hyperdense Wedge shaped prism Associated with increased urine pH Ammonium magnesium phosphate (struvite) Urease+ infection Radiopaque Hyperdense Coffin lid shaped Forms staghorn calculi Caused by Proteus, Klebsiella leading to urine alkalinization. Uric acid (Option C) Uric acid Radiolucent Visible Rhomboid Risk factors: low urine volume, acidic pH, hyperuricemia leukemia Cystine (Option D) Cystine Radiopaque Radiodense Hexagonal Hereditary defect in reabsorbing cystine, ornithine, lysine, arginine (COLA) Sodium cyanide nitroprusside test positive

questions.question: Which of the following is not true about syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)?

options.D: Patient can be clinically euvolemic to hypervolemic

questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L In SIADH, urinary sodium is typically > 40 mEq/L, not < 20 mEq/L , due to volume expansion and natriuresis. Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH) Definition Excessive ADH release leading to impaired water excretion and hyponatremia with euvolemia or hypervolemia. (Option D) Etiology CNS disturbances: Stroke, infection, subarachnoid hemorrhage, etc. Malignancies: Small cell lung cancer (most common), other cancers. Drugs: Carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, SSRIs, "Ecstasy", NSAIDs, etc. Surgery: Pain-induced ADH hypersecretion. Pulmonary diseases: Pneumonia (Option A ruled out), respiratory failure, etc. Hormone deficiency: Hypopituitarism, hypothyroidism. HIV: Associated with infections. Hereditary SIADH: V2 receptor mutation. Pathophysiology ADH function: Regulates water balance by controlling plasma osmolality; excess ADH causes water retention, leading to hyponatremia. Volume regulation: In hypovolemia, ADH release is driven by volume receptors, worsening hyponatremia. Clinical Presentation Acute hyponatremia: Nausea, vomiting, headache, seizures, coma. Chronic hyponatremia: Nonspecific symptoms (nausea, confusion, falls in elderly). Diagnosis Schwartz and Bartter Criteria: Serum sodium <135 mEq/L (Option B) Serum osmolality <275 mOsm/kg Urine sodium >40 mEq/L Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg (Option C) The absence of clinical evidence of volume depletion (like normal skin turgor, blood pressure within the reference range) The absence of hyponatremia due to other causes (like adrenal insufficiency, hypothyroidism, cardiac failure, pituitary insufficiency, renal disease with salt wastage, hepatic disease, drugs that impair renal water excretion.) Tests: Renal function, serum osmolality, cortisol levels, thyroid tests, imaging for underlying causes. Management Fluid restriction: For mild to moderate symptoms. Hypertonic saline (3%): For severe hyponatremia, with careful correction rate (<8 mEq/L in 24 hrs). Medications: Vasopressin receptor antagonists (Conivaptan, Tolvaptan) Other: Loop diuretics, salt tablets, demeclocycline, lithium. Complications Osmotic demyelination syndrome: Risk from rapid sodium correction. Severe hyponatremia: Can lead to seizures, coma, and death in acute cases. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Edition, Page 342-342, 723 Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.question: A 40-year-old male presents with complaints of episodes of palpitations, headache, and profuse sweating for the past few days. MIBG scan shows a deep-seated tumour in the adrenal medulla. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition described?

options.B: Surgical excision is the definitive treatment
options.C: Propranolol is given initially to manage hypertension
options.D: Can present as hypertension alone and sometimes with vomiting and pain abdomen

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Propranolol is given initially to manage hypertension Explanation: The above condition is characteristic of pheochromocytoma . Episodes of palpitations, profuse sweating, and headache constitute a classic triad of pheochromocytoma. The diagnosis is typically confirmed by measuring urine vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and catecholamine levels, and the definitive treatment is surgical excision. However, the initial management of hypertension in pheochromocytoma involves starting with an alpha-blocker to prevent a hypertensive crisis. Beta-blockers like propranolol are only added after adequate alpha blockade is established to avoid unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation, which could worsen the hypertension. Pheochromocytoma Description Pheochromocytomas are rare tumours arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines. Histopathology Histology of the lesion characteristically shows zellballen nests of chromaffin cells with strong positivity to chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and focally to S100. The presence of chromaffin cells in the extra-adrenal tissue is the only pathognomonic characteristic of the malignant form of the entity. Clinical features Classical triad Episode of palpitation Headache Profuse sweating The dominant sign is Hypertension Vomiting (Option D) Pain abdomen Tachycardia Anxiety Subcutaneous neurofibromas Cafe-au-lait macules Thyroid mass Axillary freckling Lisch nodules on the iris Retinal angiomas Abdominal mass Diagnosis Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines. 24-hour urine test Catecholamines (Option A) Fractionated metanephrines Total metanephrines Vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) (a metabolite of adrenaline and noradrenaline) (Option A) Imaging : CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumour. 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease. MIBG scintigraphy Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning Differential Diagnosis Hyperthyroidism Renal artery stenosis Hyperaldosteronism Cardiomyopathy Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS) Treatment The definitive treatment of pheochromocytoma is surgical resection. (Option B) Preoperative preparation of the patient has to be considered, and blood pressure should be consistently < 160/90 mm Hg. Blood pressure is controlled by alpha-adrenergic blockers (phenoxybenzamine 0.5-4 mg/kg of body weight) (vs Option C) Oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine can be used to control paroxysm. Unilateral Pheochromocytoma: Minimally invasive adrenalectomy: Preferred treatment for most unilateral adrenal pheochromocytomas. Open adrenalectomy Bilateral pheochromocytomas: Bilateral total adrenalectomy is associated with a lifelong need for steroid replacement with long-term side effects. Bilateral partial or cortical sparing adrenalectomy (open or laparoscopic) Complications Myocardial infarction Cardiogenic shock Renal Failure Pulmonary edema Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) Lactic acidosis Hypertensive retinopathy Hypertensive encephalopathy

questions.question: A patient presents with a seizure. On evaluation, urine osmolality is 1000 mOsm/kg, and serum osmolality is 270 mOsm/kg. Which electrolyte abnormality can be expected in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hyponatremia Explanation: The serum osmolality is low (270 mOsm/kg, below the normal 285–295 mOsm/kg), indicating a diluted serum, while the high urine osmolality (1000 mOsm/kg) shows that the kidneys are still concentrating urine. This pattern is characteristic of euvolemic (dilutional) hyponatremia, most commonly seen in SIADH, where inappropriate ADH secretion leads to water retention and dilution of serum sodium. This severe dilutional hyponatremia can lower sodium levels enough to trigger seizures. Causes of euvolemic (dilutional) hyponatremia include: Drugs (desmopressin, oxytocin, antidepressants, opioids, thiazide diuretics, carbamazepine or its analogues, vincristine , nicotine, antipsychotics, chlorpropamide, cyclophosphamide , nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, MDMA) Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) Increased ADH leads to water retention with near-normal sodium levels. Water overload leads to the release of ANP ( Atrial natriuretic peptide) from atria. ANP causes natriuresis which leads to euvolemic hyponatremia. No edema occurs. Causes of SIADH: Tumours Central nervous system disorders: stroke, trauma, infection, psychosis, porphyria Pulmonary disorders: pneumonia, tuberculosis, obstructive lung disease Drugs: anticonvulsants, psychotropics, antidepressants, cytotoxics, oral hypoglycaemic agents, opiates Idiopathic Addison's disease Hypothyroidism High fluid intake in conditions like primary polydipsia or potomania, caused by a low intake of solutes with relatively high fluid intake Medical testing related to excessive fluids, such as a colonoscopy or cardiac catheterisation Iatrogenic Incorrect Options: Plasma osmolality in hypernatremia (Option A) would typically be associated with increased serum osmolality (>295 mOsm/kg) due to a deficit of water in relation to sodium. Hyperkalemia (Option C) refers to an elevated level of potassium in the blood. It is not related to the given scenario as it occurs in conditions of metabolic acidosis, particularly in kidney disease, where potassium excretion is impaired. Hypokalemia (Option D) is a condition characterized by a low level of potassium in the blood. It is caused by diuretics, GI losses, and hyperaldosteronism. Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th edition, Page: 357. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470386/#: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470386/#:

questions.question: Hemodialysis is an indication for all the below conditions except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Peripheral Neuropathy Explanation: Peripheral neuropathy in CKD patients develops gradually and is less likely to improve rapidly with hemodialysis. It often requires long-term management of underlying renal disease and symptomatic treatment rather than acute dialysis. Indications of Hemodialysis: Indication Acute (AKI) Chronic(CKD) Fluid Overload Pulmonary edema Pulmonary Edema Severe Hypertension Edema resistant to diuretics Hyperkalemia >6.5 mmol/L with ECG changes (Broad QRS) Potassium resistant to treatment Uraemia Pericarditis (Option D) Encephalopathy (Option A) Uremic syndrome (anorexia, nausea, lethargy, etc.), typically when eGFR < 10 mL/min/1.73 m² Metabolic Acidosis (Option C) Severe acidosis( H+ > 79 nmol/L ; pH < 7.1) Chronic acidosis resistant to bicarbonate therapy Relative indications Bleeding diathesis due to uremia-induced platelet dysfunction Intractable anemia despite erythropoietin and iron supplementation Hyperphosphatemia despite phosphate binders Reference: Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th edition, Page 422

questions.question: Which of the following options represents the most severe manifestation of Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hyperkalaemia Explanation: Hyperkalaemia (greater than 5.0 mEq/L) is considered as one of the most severe manifestations of chronic kidney disease (CKD) (normal range: 3.5-5.0 mEq/L). As kidney function declines, the ability of the kidneys to excrete potassium decreases, leading to its accumulation. Symptoms may include muscle weakness, fatigue, palpitations, and, in severe cases, cardiac arrest. Chronic Kidney Disease Leading causes Diabetic nephropathy (Most common) Glomerulonephritis Hypertension Ischemic heart disease (Cardiorenal syndrome) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease Tubulointerstitial kidney disease Manifestations Weight loss Nausea Electrolyte Imbalances Hiccups (urea irritates gastric mucosa) Pedal oedema Muscle cramping and twitching Pruritus and skin pigmentation Uremic fetor Restless leg syndrome Uremic pericarditis Hypertension Fluid and serum electrolytes in CKD Electrolyte Imbalances Management Hypervolemic hyponatremia: High circulating aldosterone levels. Increase in water > sodium retention. Water restriction Hyperkalemia Patiromer Calcium resonium Sodium polystyrene Calcium gluconate or calcium chloride (for cardiac protection). Insulin and glucose (to shift potassium back into cells) Hypokalemia (rare): Usually due to overuse of diuretics Increase dietary intake and reduce the dose of diuretics Hyperphosphatemia Sevelamer Calcium acetate or carbonate Hypocalcemia Paricalcitol Decreased glomerular filtration rate (Option A) (GFR) is a hallmark of CKD and represents impaired kidney function. While decreased GFR is a key diagnostic criterion for CKD, it alone does not indicate the severity of the disease. The progression of CKD and its complications, such as hyperkalemia, are influenced by factors beyond the GFR. Increased creatinine (Option B) levels are indicative of reduced kidney function in CKD, they do not directly reflect the severity of the disease. Creatinine levels can also vary depending on various factors, including muscle mass, age, and hydration status. Proteinuria (Option D), the presence of excess protein in the urine, is a common finding in CKD. While it is an important marker of kidney damage and can be associated with disease progression, it is not considered the most severe manifestation of CKD. Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 2312, 2313 https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1619503/ K and pH

questions.question: A 56-year-old man presents to the casualty with severe shortness of breath and fatigue for the past 3 hours. He reports a history of vomiting and epigastric pain 2 days back, for which he took an anti-emetic. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 1. As the CBG valve of this patient showed 356mg/dL, the physician advises immediate ABG analysis, which reveals a pH=7.32, pCO 2 =38mEq/L, and HCO 3 -=15mEq/L. This report showed a type of acidosis with an increased anion gap. Which of the following conditions does not belong to the same classification of metabolic acidosis as in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Renal aciduria Renal aciduria refers to a condition characterized by the inability of the kidneys to effectively reabsorb bicarbonate or excrete hydrogen ions, leading to a decreased bicarbonate and metabolic acidosis. However, renal aciduria presents with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA). It is a form of renal tubular acidosis (RTA). Metabolic acidosis High anion gap (MUDPILES) (HAGMA) Non-anion gap (USED PART) (NAGMA) M ethanol poisoning U remia: AKI, CKD (Option A) D iabetic ketoacidosis P aracetamol poisoning I ron and isoniazid L actic acidosis (Option B) E thylene glycol poisoning S alicylate poisoning (Option D) U : Urinary diversion / Ureterenterostomy S : Small Bowel Fistula, S pironolactone and K-sparing diuretics, S aline infusion (rapid infusion) E : Extra Chloride D : Diarrhea P : Pancreatic fistula A : Addison, Acetazolamide R: RTA (Renal tubular acidosis ) T : Tenofovir, Topiramate Reduced anion gap: Multiple myeloma and nephrotic syndrome Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 359 - 361, 364

questions.question: A 29-year-old male patient presents with multiple oral and genital ulcers. The patient claims these ulcers resolve spontaneously and that she experiences such episodes at least four times a year. Ocular examination reveals features of anterior uveitis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Behcet’s disease Explanation: This patient presents with classic features of Behcet's Disease: Young adult male Mucocutaneous manifestations (oral/genital ulcers) Ocular involvement (uveitis) Behcet's disease is a chronic autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers. It is a multi-systemic vasculitis that can affect blood vessels of all sizes. One of the common manifestations of Behcet's disease is uveitis Behcet’s Disease- Pathogenesis and Clinical Features Category Features Clinical Significance Pathogenesis T-cell mediated immunity Th1 cell activation Elevated cytokines (IL-1, TNF- α ) Neutrophilic vasculitis No specific autoantibodies Auto-inflammatory rather than autoimmune Affects vessels of all sizes Treatment targets inflammation Mucocutaneous Oral ulcers (97-99%) Genital ulcers (>80%) Erythema nodosum Pathergy reaction Often initial presentation Oral ulcers heal without scarring Genital ulcers leave scars Major Organ Involvement Uveitis (>50%) Vascular (25%) Neurologic (5-10%) Arthritis (non-erosive) More severe in males Ocular disease can cause blindness Vascular involvement can be fatal

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly describes an ideal candidate for a renal graft transplant in a patient with diabetic nephropathy?

options.A: The survival rate of graft is 95% in the first year
options.B: The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year
options.C: The life expectancy is doubled in a diabetic patient with renal transplant
options.D: The treatment of chronic rejection has improved over the last 10 years

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year Explanation: Renal transplantation is considered the treatment of choice for end-stage renal disease (ESRD) in patients with diabetic nephropathy with eGFR <20 ml/min. Renal transplant procedure: Preparation of the donor kidney: inspected and examined. The left kidney is preferred as it has a longer left renal vein. Operative technique: The donor kidney is transplanted into one of the iliac fossae (retroperitoneal location) leaving the native kidney in situ. Hence, a total of 3 kidneys in the recipient. The donor renal vein is anastomosed end to side to the external or common iliac vein. In a cadaveric donor, the renal artery is anastomosed end to side to the external or common iliac artery. In live donors, end-to-end anastomosis to the divided internal iliac artery is used more commonly due to the lack of an aortic patch (Carrel’s patch) . Indications for renal transplantation: End-stage renal disease caused by: G lomerulonephritis D iabetic nephropathy H ypertensive nephrosclerosis R enal vascular disease P olycystic Kidney disease/Chronic P yelonephritis O bstructive uropathy S LE A nalgesic nephropathy M etabolic disease (oxalosis, amyloid) Mnemonic: GD for HR POSt at 4 AM "The survival rate of the graft is 95% in the first year," (Option A) is an overgeneralization. While the survival rate of renal grafts in the first year can be relatively high, it is not consistently 95% for all patients. "The life expectancy is doubled in a diabetic patient with renal transplant," (Option C) is not entirely accurate. While renal transplantation can improve the quality of life and increase life expectancy in patients with ESRD, it does not necessarily double the life expectancy. "The treatment of chronic rejection has improved over the last 10 years," (Option D) is not directly addressed in the given statement. Chronic rejection remains a challenge in renal transplantation.

questions.question: Calculate the sodium deficit in the patient, who weighs 60 kg, using the provided serum electrolyte values: pH of 7.42, sodium (Na+) level of 120 mEq/L, and serum chloride (CI-) level of 90 mEq/L.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D)720 mEq Explanation: Sodium Deficit Formula: Sodium deficit = (Desired Na I - Actual Na I ) × Total Body Water (TBW) Total Body Water (TBW): TBW = 0.6 × Body Weight(for males) = 0.5 x Body Weight(for females) TBW for this patient: 0.6 × 60 kg = 36 litres Desired Sodium Increase: The target increase in serum sodium = 140 mEq/L - 120 mEq/L = 20 mEq/L Sodium Deficit Calculation: Sodium deficit = 20 mEq/L × 36 L = 720mEq Safe Increase in Sodium: In acute symptomatic hyponatremia with seizures, an initial rapid correction of 4-6 mEq/L in the first few hours is recommended to stabilize neurological symptoms. The total correction should not exceed 8-12 mEq/L in the first 24 hours to avoid complications such as osmotic demyelination syndrome. Reference: Sodium deficit correction

questions.question: As per KDIGO, which of the following falls under G3b?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 30-44 Explanation: This range corresponds to Stage 3b of CKD , which is classified as a moderate to severe decrease in kidney function, with GFR between 30-44 mL/min/1.73m². According to the Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) classification for chronic kidney disease (CKD): GFR: A GFR of 50 mL/min falls into Stage 3 CKD (G3a), defined as 30–59 mL/min. Albuminuria: An albuminuria level of 12 mg/g is categorised as A1 (normal to mildly increased), which is <30 mg/g. Combining these classifications: GFR Stage: G3a (Stage 3) Albuminuria Category: A1 G F R The prognosis of CKD, according to KDIGO 2012 classification Persistent albuminuria A1 A2 A3 Normal to mild increase Moderate increase Severe increase <30mg/g 30-300 mg/g >300mg/g G1 Normal or high >=90 Low risk Moderate risk High risk G2 Mildly decreased 60-89 Low risk Moderate risk High risk G3a Mild to moderate decrease 45-59 Moderate risk High risk Very high risk G3b Moderate to severe decrease 30-44 High risk Very high risk Very high risk G4 Severe decrease 15-29 Very high risk Very high risk Very high risk G5 Kidney failure <15 Very high risk Very high risk Very high risk 45-59 (Option A): This corresponds to Stage 3a. 60-89 (Option B): This corresponds to Stage 2. 15-29 (Option D): This corresponds to Stage 4. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2309.

questions.question: A mutation in the gene for the aquaporin channel leads to which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Nephrogenic DI A mutation in the gene for the aquaporin channel leads to Nephrogenic DI. Diabetes Insipidus (DI): It is a disorder characterized by excessive hypotonic urinary output (>50 mL/kg body weight per 24 hours) and polydipsia (>3 litres/day). It results from an inability to concentrate urine adequately due to a deficiency or insensitivity to antidiuretic hormone (ADH). Types of Diabetes Insipidus: Feature Central DI Nephrogenic DI Primary Polydipsia Gestational DI Definition Deficiency of AVP (Arginine vasopressin) secretion from the pituitary gland. Kidneys are unable to respond to AVP, even if levels are normal. Excessive water intake, suppressing AVP secretion. Increased activity of placental enzyme degrading AVP during pregnancy. Causes Acquired : Head trauma, tumours, granulomas, infections, inflammation, toxins, vascular events, hypoxia. Acquired : Drugs (lithium, demeclocycline), metabolic disorders (hypercalcaemia, hypokalaemia), obstruction, vascular issues, granulomas, tumours, and infiltration. Dipsogenic : Inappropriate thirst, head trauma, brain diseases. Increased placental vasopressinase activity. Psychogenic : Psychiatric conditions, compulsive water drinking. Genetic : Mutations in the AVP–neurophysin II or WFS1 genes. Genetic: Mutations in the V2 receptor or aquaporin-2 genes. Iatrogenic : Belief in the health benefits of excessive water intake. Basal Plasma AVP Low or undetectable (<1 pg/mL). Normal or elevated (>1 pg/mL). Low due to suppression by excessive water intake. Low due to increased degradation. Urine Osmolarity Low (<280 mOsm/L). Low (<280 mOsm/L). Low (<280 mOsm/L) but can temporarily concentrate with fluid deprivation. Low (<280 mOsm/L). Plasma Osmolarity Increased Increased Decreased Increased Fluid Deprivation Test Urine does not concentrate. AVP or desmopressin injection increases urine osmolarity in severe CDI. Urine does not concentrate. AVP or desmopressin injection has no effect on severe NDI. Plasma osmolarity and sodium increase above normal without urine concentration. Not typically performed during pregnancy. MRI Posterior pituitary bright spot absent or small. Posterior pituitary bright- spot may be faint or absent. Posterior pituitary bright spot present. Not routinely used for diagnosis. Desmopressin (DDAVP) Trial Abolishes polyuria and polydipsia; reduces plasma osmolarity/sodium. No effect on urine output, fluid intake, or plasma osmolarity/sodium. Eliminates polyuria but not polydipsia, leading to hyponatremia. Effective in controlling symptoms. Plasma Copeptin Low or undetectable. It may be normal or elevated. Suppressed due to low AVP. It may be low due to AVP degradation. Treatment Desmopressin (DDAVP). Thiazide diuretics, amiloride, low-sodium diet, prostaglandin inhibitors. Behavioral therapy, education about overhydration. Desmopressin (DDAVP). Resolution Lifelong treatment usually needed for acquired CDI Genetic forms may improve. Dependent on the underlying cause Lithium-induced NDI may persist. Dependent on behavioural modification and addressing the underlying cause. Usually, it resolves after delivery. Liddle’s syndrome (Option A) is caused by an inherited gain-of-function mutation in genes regulating the ENaC (epithelial sodium channel) in the collecting duct. Cystic fibrosis (Option C) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, which encodes a chloride channel in the luminal plasma membranes of epithelial cells. Bartter syndrome (Option D) results from loss-of-function

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presents to the OPD with palpitation and weight loss. On examination of her legs the following lesion was found which on applying pressure, the indentation does not persist on release. ECG shows sinus rhythm. What is the probable cause of the oedema?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Nephrotic syndrome: Explanation: Based on the given clinical presentation and examination findings, the most probable cause for the oedema, in this case, is nephrotic syndrome . Nephrotic Syndrome Clinical manifestations Pathophysiology Proteinuria The damage to the glomerular filtration barrier leads to increased permeability to proteins . Odema Hypoalbuminemia Due to urinary loss of albumin being more than its synthesis by the liver. Muehrcke's lines (linear white lines in the nail bed seen in hypoalbuminemia) Hyperlipidemia Xanthoma and xanthelasma can be appreciated. Hypercoagulability This can be due to factors like: Due to the loss of anticoagulant proteins like Protein C/ Protein S/ Antithrombin III Ferritin deficiency History of factor V Leiden mutation Increased production of procoagulant factors by the liver. Infections Loss of immunoglobulins in urine causes hypogammaglobulinemia , increasing susceptibility to infections. Diagnostic criteria for Nephrotic syndrome Essential findings Proteinuria of > 3.5 g/day Urine PCR > 2g protein/g of creatinine Hypoalbuminemia - serum Albumin < 2.5 gm% Oedema due to reduced oncotic pressure Other findings

questions.question: A hepatitis B-positive person came to your OPD on routine urine massive proteinuria (> 3.5 g/day). Further renal biopsy was performed as below. Identify the disease.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Membranous glomerulonephritis Explanation: Investigations of Membranous Nephropathy/ glomerulonephritis: Kidney function tests reveal increased creatinine Urine Protein: >2gm protein/gram of urinary creatinine Renal biopsy: Light Microscopy: Reveals uniform basement membrane thickening along peripheral capillary loops. Immunofluorescence: Diffuse granular deposits of IgG and C3 Electron Microscopy: Dense subepithelial deposits Spike & dome appearance (arrows & asterisk) Autoantibody Testing: Autoantibodies against M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) are present in 70% of cases. Thrombospondin type-1 domain containing 7A (THSD7A) (3-10%) Secondary MGN often lacks these autoantibodies. Management of Membranous Nephropathy: Symptomatic treatment : Manage oedema (Thiazide diuretics), dyslipidemia, and hypertension (ACE inhibitors/ARBs) Immunosuppressive Therapy: For primary MGN with persistent proteinuria (>3g/24 h) Corticosteroids Cyclophosphamide Chlorambucil Mycophenolate mofetil Cyclosporine Rituximab (anti-CD20 antibody) Prophylactic Anticoagulation may be recommended for patients with hypoalbuminemia due to the risk of thrombotic complications. Complications: Increased risk of Renal vein thrombosis . Others : Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism due to hypercoagulability associated with nephrotic syndrome. Prognosis: One-third of patients progress to more severe disease. One-third experience spontaneous remission. One-third maintain stable disease. Factors associated with a poorer prognosis include male gender, older age, hypertension, and persistent nephrotic-range proteinuria. Incorrect Options: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Option A) is characterized by scarring and sclerosis of certain glomeruli in

questions.question: Which of the following agents is most likely causing the condition in a 60-year-old woman, who had a kidney transplant 2 months ago, and is now experiencing a high fever, severe difficulty in breathing, and a dry cough with a hacking sound? A chest x-ray shows widespread interstitial infiltrates in both lungs, and urine examination reveals the presence of cells with an 'owl-eye' appearance.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cytomegalovirus Explanation: Cytomegalovirus infection is the most common opportunistic infection post renal transplantation, and it usually occurs within 1- 6 months of transplantation. Complications following Renal transplant Graft rejection Hyperacute, acute and chronic Opportunistic infections < 1 Month: Wound infection, HSV, UTI, Oral candidiasis 1-6 Months: CMV (most common), HBV, HCV, Pneumocystis carinii, Listeria >6 Months: BK Virus , Aspergillus, Nocardia, HBV, HCV, HZV Hypercalcemia This may indicate failure of parathyroid gland regression post-transplant. Anemia Common post-transplant, often due to immunosuppressive medications. Gastrointestinal bleeding can occur from steroid use. Chronic hepatitis Particularly from hepatitis B virus, which can progress over time. Skin and lip cancers Most common malignancy The leading causes of death among kidney transplant recipients include: Cardiovascular events (29%) Infections (18%) Malignancies (17%) Reference: Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page: 2330.

questions.question: A patient exhibits symptoms of increased urination, nighttime urination, and involuntary urination, along with a recorded 24-hour urine volume of 7 litres. He has a urine osmolarity of 260 mOsm/L. The ADH assay shows a recorded value of 0.8 pg/ml, and an MRI of the brain reveals the absence of a bright spot on T1-weighted imaging. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pituitary DI Explanation: The above case is most suggestive of pituitary diabetes insipidus. The absence of a pituitary bright spot is suggestive of central DI. Feature Central DI (Option C) Nephrogenic DI (Option A) Primary Polydipsia (Option B) Gestational DI Definition Deficiency of AVP (Arginine vasopressin) secretion from the pituitary gland . Kidneys are unable to respond to AVP, even if levels are normal. Excessive water intake suppresses AVP secretion. Increased activity of placental enzyme degrading AVP during pregnancy. Causes Acquired : Head trauma, tumours, granulomas, infections, inflammation, toxins, vascular events, hypoxia. Acquired : Drugs (lithium, demeclocycline), metabolic disorders (hypercalcaemia, hypokalaemia), obstruction, vascular issues, granulomas, tumours, and infiltration. Dipsogenic : Inappropriate thirst, head trauma, brain diseases. Increased placental vasopressinase activity. Psychogenic : Psychiatric conditions, compulsive water drinking. Genetic : Mutations in the AVP–neurophysin II or WFS1 genes. Genetic : Mutations in the V2 receptor or aquaporin-2 genes. Iatrogenic : Belief in the health benefits of excessive water intake. Basal Plasma AVP Low or undetectable (<1 pg/mL). Normal or elevated (>1 pg/mL). Low due to suppression by excessive water intake. Low due to increased degradation. Urine Osmolarity Low (<280 mOsm/L). Low (<280 mOsm/L). Low (<280 mOsm/L) but can temporarily concentrate with fluid deprivation. Low (<280 mOsm/L). Plasma Osmolarity Increased Increased Decreased Increased Fluid Deprivation Test Urine does not concentrate. AVP or desmopressin injection increases urine osmolarity in severe CDI. Urine does not concentrate. AVP or desmopressin injection does not affect severe NDI. Plasma osmolarity and sodium increase above normal without urine concentration. Not typically performed during pregnancy. MRI Posterior pituitary bright spot absent or small. The posterior pituitary bright- spot may be faint or absent. Posterior pituitary bright spot present. Not routinely used for diagnosis. Desmopressin (DDAVP) Trial Abolishes polyuria and polydipsia; reduces plasma osmolarity/sodium. No effect on urine output, fluid intake, or plasma osmolarity/sodium. Eliminates polyuria but not polydipsia, leading to hyponatremia. Effective in controlling symptoms. Plasma Copeptin Low or undetectable. It may be normal or elevated. Suppressed due to low AVP. It may be low due to AVP degradation. Treatment Desmopressin (DDAVP). Thiazide diuretics, amiloride, low-sodium diet, prostaglandin inhibitors. Behavioural therapy, education about overhydration. Desmopressin (DDAVP). Resolution Lifelong treatment is usually needed for acquired CDI Genetic forms may improve. Dependent on the underlying cause Lithium-induced NDI may persist. Dependent on behavioural modification and addressing the underlying cause. Usually, it resolves after delivery. In mannitol infusion (Option D) , the urine osmolality is >300 mOsm/L.

questions.question: A 10-year-old male child presents with headache and cola-colored urine. His parents report throat pain 2 weeks ago. On examination, red blood cells are present in urine and his KFT is increased two fold. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Post-infectious Glomerulonephritis Explanation: The clinical manifestations indicate Post-infectious Glomerulonephritis . This condition typically occurs after an infection, most commonly caused by Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus . The diagnosis is supported by the classic presentation of cola-colored urine and recent history of throat infection . The condition develops due to formation of immune complexes by streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin B (SPEB) , which get distributed in renal parenchyma and damage blood vessels, leading to increased protein excretion and hematuria. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) Cause Group A β -Hemolytic streptococci Pathogenesis Immune-complex mediated ( Type III hypersensitivity reaction) Clinical manifestations It is more common in children and young adults. History of impetigo (2-6 weeks) or pharyngitis (1-3 weeks ). Pulmonary oedema (shortness of breath, cough, chest pain) Periorbital and pedal oedema Hypertensive encephalopathy: Abrupt rise in BP Headache Loss of consciousness Features of uremia include fatigue, weakness, confusion, swelling over body parts, shortness of breath, abnormal urine output, nausea, and vomiting. Test for antibodies Anti- DNAse Anti-Hyaluronidase ASO (antistreptolysin O) titer Lab findings Urine analysis: Red-colored urine, which turns dark ( cola-colored ) on standing ( hematuria ). Raised values of renal function test (serum creatinine, urea, etc). Raised serum potassium Low serum levels of C3, IgG & CH50 Normal serum C4 level. Pathological findings Gross findings: Flea-bitten appearance of kidneys Light microscopy: Hypercellular glomeruli (increased number of neutrophils, macrophages, endothelial and mesangial cells). Electron microscopy: Subepithelial humps (due to immune complex deposition) Immunofluorescence study: A starry-sky appearance (Granular) is observed (due to immune complex deposition). Management Self-limiting disorder Conservative and supportive management involves: HTN crisis : Labetalol (IV), sodium nitroprusside Pulmonary edema: Furosemide Antibiotics (Benzathine penicillin) Dialysis if needed Minimal change disease (Option A) is characterized by minimal changes in the glomeruli on microscopic examination and commonly presents in children with proteinuria, edema, and hypoalbuminemia. The absence of significant proteinuria and presence of hematuria rules out this diagnosis. Membranous Glomerulonephritis (Option B) typically presents with thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to immune complex deposits, causing proteinuria, edema, and hypoalbuminemia. The acute onset and recent history of throat infection makes this diagnosis less likely. IgA nephropathy (Option D) is characterized by IgA deposits in the mesangium and typically develops within 48 hours after an upper respiratory tract infection. The timing of symptoms (2 weeks after throat pain) and the classic cola-colored urine presentation makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.question: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used classify—
questions.explanation: Network) and RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss, End-stage kidney disease) criteria are used to classify and diagnose acute kidney injury. These criteria consider changes in serum creatinine levels, urine output, and the time frame in which these changes occur to determine the severity of acute kidney injury. Incorrect options: Option B. Chronic renal failure This option is incorrect. AKIN and RIFLE criteria are not used to classify chronic renal failure. Chronic renal failure is a progressive, long-term condition characterized by a permanent loss of kidney function over time. It is usually diagnosed and classified based on the estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) and the presence of kidney damage lasting for at least three months. Option C. Acute glomerulonephritis This option is incorrect. AKIN and RIFLE criteria are not used to classify acute glomerulonephritis. Acute glomerulonephritis refers to the inflammation and damage of the glomeruli in the kidneys. It is typically diagnosed through clinical symptoms, laboratory tests, and kidney biopsies. Option D. Nephrotic syndrome This option is incorrect. AKIN and RIFLE criteria are not used to classify nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is a collection of symptoms characterized by increased proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia. It is usually diagnosed based on clinical findings, urine tests, and blood tests.

questions.question: In the ICU, a patient experiencing renal failure presents with vomiting. Analysis of arterial blood gases reveals a pH level of 7.4, sodium (Na+) concentration of 14 mEq/L, chloride (CI-) concentration of 100 mEq/L, bicarbonate (HCO3-) concentration of 24 mEq/L, and a partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 40 mmHg. What metabolic abnormality is most likely occurring?

options.C: High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis
options.D: High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis

questions.explanation: sodium level suggests hyponatremia, which is associated with metabolic alkalosis. The elevated anion gap indicates the presence of a metabolic acidosis, likely due to renal failure or other underlying causes Let's analyze the given ABG values: pH: 7.4 (within the normal range, indicating no primary acid-base disturbance) Na+: 14 mEq/L (low) Cl-: 100 mEq/L (within the normal range) HCO3-: 24 mEq/L (within the normal range) PaCO2: 40 mmHg (within the normal range) From these values, we can determine the likely metabolic abnormality. The low sodium (Na+) level suggests hyponatremia, which can occur in patients with renal failure. In this case, the patient has a concurrent high anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis. Incorrect Option: Option A. Normal ABG: This option is incorrect because there is evidence of an abnormality in the ABG analysis (low sodium level). Option B. Normal anion gap, metabolic acidosis: This option is incorrect because the anion gap is elevated in this case. The normal anion gap is associated with a chloride-based metabolic acidosis, which is not present here. Option D. High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis: This option is incorrect because there is evidence of a metabolic acidosis in the ABG analysis (elevated anion gap). Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21e

questions.question: All the following are features of polycystic disease of kidneys except :
questions.explanation: is not a typical feature of PKD, in some cases, PKD can lead to the development of renal cell carcinoma, which may cause erythrocytosis as a paraneoplastic syndrome. However, this is not a common finding in most cases of PKD. Incorrect Options: Option A - Hematuria : Hematuria, which is the presence of blood in the urine, can occur in PKD due to the rupture or bleeding within the cysts. It is a common symptom of PKD. Option B - Hypertension : High blood pressure is a common feature of PKD. The cysts in the kidneys can interfere with normal kidney function, leading to increased renin secretion and subsequent hypertension. Option C - Renal Failure : PKD is a progressive condition that can eventually lead to kidney failure. The numerous cysts gradually replace the healthy kidney tissue, impairing kidney function over time. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the probable reason for the quadriparesis developed by a 60-year-old patient after being treated with a significant amount of hypertonic fluids for 24 hours following a history of hyponatremia?
questions.explanation: with a large volume of hypertonic fluids over a short period of time. Following this treatment, the patient developed quadriparesis. These findings are suggestive of central pontine myelinolysis (Choice C). Central pontine myelinolysis (CPM) is a condition characterized by the destruction of the myelin sheath in the central portion of the pons, which is a part of the brainstem. It is typically associated with rapid correction of hyponatremia, especially when the correction occurs too quickly. In this case, the hypertonic fluids caused a rapid increase in serum sodium levels, leading to osmotic changes in the brain and subsequent damage to the myelin sheath in the pons. Incorrect Option : Option A . Brain infarct: Brain infarct (Choice A) refers to the obstruction of blood flow to a specific area of the brain, resulting in tissue damage. While hyponatremia can contribute to the development of cerebral edema and increase the risk of brain infarction, the rapid correction of hyponatremia in this case is more consistent with CPM. Option B . Brainstem injury: Brainstem injury (Choice B) can result from trauma or other causes and can lead to a range of neurological symptoms. However, the rapid development of quadriparesis following the treatment with hypertonic fluids suggests a more specific diagnosis of CPM. Option D . Rare cause of hypernatremia: Hypernatremia refers to an elevated serum sodium level. In this case, the patient presented with hyponatremia and received hypertonic fluids, so the development of hypernatremia is not likely to be the cause of the patient's condition. Therefore, Choice D is an incorrect option.

questions.question: AKIN and RIFLE criteria is used for classification of which of the folowing coditions?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Acute kidney injury Explanation: The AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) and RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss, End-stage kidney disease) criteria are used to classify and stage acute kidney injury (AKI). These criteria help healthcare professionals assess the severity of AKI and guide treatment decisions. RIFLE Classification Table for Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): Class SCr/GFR Criteria Urine Output (UO) Criteria R isk ↑ SCr × 1.5 or ↓ GFR > 25% < 0.5 mL/kg/h for 6 hours I njury ↑ SCr × 2 or ↓ GFR > 50% < 0.5 mL/kg/h for 12 hours F ailure ↑ SCr × 3 or ↓ GFR > 75% or Baseline SCr ≥ 353.6 µ mol/L ( ≥ 4 mg/dL) + ↑ SCr > 44.2 µ mol/L (> 0.5 mg/dL) < 0.3 mL/kg/h for 24 hours or Anuria for 12 hours L oss of Kidney Function Complete loss of kidney function for > 4 weeks - E nd-Stage Kidney Disease Complete loss of kidney function for > 3 months - SCr = Serum Creatinine GFR = Glomerular Filtration Rate UO = Urine Output AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) Classification Table for AKI: Stage Serum Creatinine (SCr) Criteria Urine Output (UO) Criteria 1 ↑ SCr ≥ 26.5 µ mol/L ( ≥ 0.3 mg/dL) or ↑ SCr 150–200% (1.5–2 times) < 0.5 mL/kg/h for > 6 hours 2 ↑ SCr > 200–300% (> 2–3 times) < 0.5 mL/kg/h for > 12 hours 3 Baseline SCr ≥ 353.6 µ mol/L ( ≥ 4 mg/dL) + ↑ SCr ≥ 44.2 µ mol/L ( ≥ 0.5 mg/dL) or ↑ SCr > 300% (> 3 times) or Patients requiring Renal Replacement Therapy (RRT) , regardless of SCr or UO at the time of initiation. < 0.3 mL/kg/h for 24 hours or Anuria for 12 hours Reference: Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th edition, Page 411 https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5094385/#s2 https://kdigo.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/KDIGO-2012-AKI-Guideline-English.pdf

questions.question: A patient has undergone an acute renal allograft transplantation. What would indicate its rejection?

options.A: Rise of creatinine by more than 10% is suggestive of acute rejection.
options.B: Rise of creatinine by more than 5% is suggestive of acute rejection.
options.C: Serum creatinine does not rise in acute renal allograft rejection.
options.D: Any rise in serum creatinine will be suggestive of acute renal allograft rejection.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Any rise in serum creatinine will be suggestive of acute renal allograft rejection. indicators of graft dysfunction. A rise in serum creatinine, even if small or unexplained, necessitates further investigation to rule out acute rejection. Acute Renal Allograft Rejection Acute renal allograft rejection occurs when the recipient's immune system identifies the transplanted kidney as foreign, leading to cellular or antibody-mediated immune responses that cause kidney inflammation and damage. Clinical Presentation: Typically occurs weeks to months post-transplant, but can occur later if immunosuppression is reduced. Symptoms may include reduced urine output, graft tenderness, fever, and malaise, though not always present. Any unexplained increase in creatinine should raise suspicion for acute rejection. Types of Acute Rejection: Cellular Rejection (T-cell Mediated): T-cells attack the graft, causing inflammation and tissue damage. Antibody-Mediated Rejection (AMR): Antibodies attack the donor endothelial cells, leading to endothelial injury and microvascular thrombosis. Confirmatory Investigation: Renal biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing acute rejection and determining the type of rejection. Biopsy findings: Cellular rejection: T-cell infiltration and inflammation. AMR: Endothelial damage and microvascular inflammation. Treatment: Cellular rejection: Treated with increased immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., steroids, ATG). AMR: Requires treatments like plasmapheresis, IVIG, or rituximab. Type of Rejection Hyperacute Rejection Acute Rejection Chronic Rejection Acute Cellular Rejection Acute Antibody-Mediated Rejection Description Occurs immediately after transplant. Mediated by preformed antibodies against graft endothelial cells. Occurs within days to weeks after transplant. Mediated by CD8+ T cells and CD4+ T cells. Antibodies bind to graft endothelial cells, leading to complement activation and inflammation. Develops over months to years. Mediated by T cells. Timing Minutes to hours after transplant. Days to weeks after transplant. Days to months after transplant. Months to years after transplant. Type of Hypersensitivity Reaction Type 2 (Cytotoxic Hypersensitivity) Type 4 (Cell-mediated Hypersensitivity) Type 2 (Cytotoxic Hypersensitivity) Type 4 (Cell-mediated Hypersensitivity) Immunologic Mechanism Pre-existing antibodies activate complement. Causes endothelial injury and thrombosis. CD8+ T cells destroy graft cells. CD4+ T cells induce inflammation. Antibodies against graft antigens activate complement. Leads to graft inflammation. T cell-mediated response causes graft fibrosis and dysfunction. Treatment No treatment. Requires graft removal. Immunosuppressive therapy (steroids, antithymocyte globulin). Plasmapheresis, IVIG, rituximab, steroids. No definitive treatment. Supportive care and immunosuppression. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 235-237.

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with hematuria. Which of the following are seen in glomerular hematuria? Statements: Brown-colored urine Dysuria absent Crystals present Edema rare
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, 4 Explanation: Glomerular hematuria presents with brown-colored urine due to RBC breakdown, absence of dysuria as it is not due to lower urinary tract infection, and edema may occur in nephritic syndrome, but is not rare; however, crystals are not a feature of glomerular hematuria. Glomerular Hematuria Glomerular hematuria occurs due to damage to the glomerular filtration barrier, leading to the leakage of red blood cells (RBCs) into the urine. Causes: Glomerulonephritis (Post-streptococcal, IgA nephropathy, lupus nephritis, membranoproliferative GN) Small Vessel Vasculitis (ANCA-associated vasculitis, Goodpasture’s syndrome) Hereditary Conditions (Alport syndrome, Thin basement membrane disease) Features Color: Cola-colored or smoky brown urine Dysmorphic RBCs (acanthocytes, Mickey Mouse cells) Proteinuria: Often present, especially if associated with nephritic syndrome Presence of RBC casts (diagnostic of glomerular origin) Clots absent (distinguishes from non-glomerular hematuria) Serum Markers : Often associated with increased serum creatinine. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 337.

questions.question: What is the recommended treatment for nephrotic syndrome in children?
questions.explanation: which is the most common cause in children . Corticosteroids work by reducing inflammation and suppressing the immune response that leads to proteinuria. The typical initial treatment consists of oral prednisone, with most patients showing a response within 4-8 weeks of therapy. Feature Steroid-Responsive Nephrotic Syndrome Steroid-Resistant Nephrotic Syndrome Definition Nephrotic syndrome that responds well to corticosteroid treatment. Nephrotic syndrome that does not improve despite adequate corticosteroid treatment (e.g., prednisolone at 2 mg/kg/day for 6 weeks). Types: Initial Steroid Resistance: Lack of response from the onset. Late Steroid Resistance: Resistance develops after initial response. Common Type Minimal Change Nephrotic Syndrome (MCNS) accounts for about 80% of cases in children. It is often associated with Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) or genetic mutations affecting podocytes. Diagnosis Diagnosed without kidney biopsy; characterised by heavy proteinuria, low serum albumin, and no significant glomerular damage. Further investigation (e.g., kidney biopsy) is required to determine the underlying cause. Management Responds to high-dose corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone) , leading to remission of proteinuria and oedema within 10-14 days. Treatment may include immunosuppressive agents, calcineurin inhibitors, or other therapies, as corticosteroids are often ineffective. Steroids and cyclophosphamide (Option B): While this combination may be used in steroid-resistant cases or specific types of nephrotic syndrome, it is not the first-line treatment for nephrotic syndrome in children, which is mainly due to Minimal change disease. The addition of cyclophosphamide is reserved for cases that fail to respond to steroids alone or have frequent relapses. Also, the potential toxicity of cyclophosphamide makes it unsuitable as an initial therapy. Cyclophosphamide (Option C): Using cyclophosphamide alone is not the recommended initial treatment for nephrotic syndrome in children. It is typically used as a second-line agent in steroid-resistant cases or specific pathological variants. ACE inhibitors (Option D): While ACE inhibitors can help reduce proteinuria and are often used as adjunctive therapy, they are not the primary treatment for nephrotic syndrome. They are typically used in conjunction with immunosuppressive therapy, which is the mainstay for treating the underlying cause of nephrotic syndrome. Reference: OP Ghai, Essential Pediatrics, 10th Edition, Page 500, 503

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes presents for a routine follow-up. Her serum creatinine and potassium levels are normal, but she has microalbuminuria and an HbA1c of 8%. Her blood pressure and pulse are within normal limits, and she is currently on metformin for diabetes management. What should be the next step in her management?

options.C: Stop Metformin and start a different OHA

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Start an ACE inhibitor. Explanation: Starting ACE inhibitors early in the progression of diabetic nephropathy, particularly with the presence of microalbuminuria, has demonstrated significant benefits in reducing the risk of kidney failure and cardiovascular events . Management of Diabetic nephropathy Oral Hypoglycemic agents (OHAs) SGLT2 inhibitors lower the risk of cardiovascular events and renal failure; they are also recently approved for HFpEF. For HbA1C < 9.5%, OHAs can be used Metformin is withheld if eGFR is < 30 mL/min/1.73 m2 (Option C) , and drugs safe in renal failure can be used like Glipizide Linagliptin Repaglinide Insulin 80% of the calculated dose is started if HbA1C > 9.5% (Option B) Antihypertensives In the presence of microalbuminuria, ACEi and ARBs have shown evidence to slow the progression of nephropathy if started in early stages. In hypertension, for BP > 130/90, ACEi or ARBs are preferred If BP is still not under control, Calcium channel blocker (CCB) can be added Thiazide diuretic - in the presence of oedema (Option A) If eGFR <30 ml/min, then the diuretic used - Metolazone. ACEi/ARB comes with a side effect of hyperkalemia; hence, regular monitoring of potassium is necessary. In the presence of hyperkalemia , ACEi/ARB is replaced by CCB Alpha blocker (Prazosin) - hyperkalemia in ESRD. For Hyperkalemia K Binding resins (Bind to potassium in the gastrointestinal tract and promote its excretion) Sodium polystyrene sulfonate Patiromer Sodium zirconate Renal Transplant If eGFR is < 20 mL/min/1.73 m2 . Reference: Davidson’s Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 746 Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page 2316, 2344, 2345, 3124

questions.question: Which of the following is most likely based on the lab values given? Blood pH: 7.3 (indicating mild acidosis) Sodium (Na+): 134 mEq/L (mildly decreased) Potassium (K+): 2.8 mEq/L (hypokalemia) Chloride (Cl-): 113 mEq/L (elevated) Bicarbonate (HCO II ): 12 mEq/L (low, indicating metabolic acidosis) Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN): 3 mg/dL (low-normal) Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL (normal) Urinary pH: 9.4 (alkaline)
questions.explanation: characterized by the inability of the distal tubules of the kidneys to excrete hydrogen ions, leading to an alkaline urinary pH (usually >5.5). Patients typically have a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia (low potassium), and a low serum bicarbonate level. In this case, the blood pH is mildly acidotic (7.3), with a low HCO II (12 mEq/L) and hypokalemia (K+ of 2.8 mEq/L). The urine pH is markedly alkaline (9.4), which is consistent with RTA Type 1. Incorrect Options: Option B - RTA Type 2 (Proximal RTA) : RTA Type 2, or proximal RTA, involves a defect in bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, leading to a loss of bicarbonate in the urine and subsequent metabolic acidosis. Urine is typically acidic (pH < 5.5) after the loss of bicarbonate is maximized. Patients can have hypokalemia, but the urinary pH would not remain as high (9.4) after the plasma bicarbonate is depleted, making this less likely. Option C - RTA Type 4 : RTA Type 4 is characterized by hyperkalemia (high potassium) and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. This type results from hypoaldosteronism or aldosterone resistance. In this case, the patient has hypokalemia (K+ of 2.8 mEq/L), not hyperkalemia, making RTA Type 4 an unlikely diagnosis. Option D - High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA) : HAGMA is characterized by a high anion gap due to the accumulation of unmeasured anions (e.g., lactate, ketoacids, toxins). The calculated anion gap here is normal (AG = Na - [Cl + HCO I ] = 134 - [113 + 12] = 9), which does not support a diagnosis of HAGMA. Therefore, HAGMA is not the correct answer.

questions.question: A patient having hypertension is on thiazides and is complaining of fatigue and hypokalemia. Which of the following drugs can prevent potassium loss?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Amiloride Explanation: Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that acts by inhibiting the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) in the distal nephron. When used in combination with thiazide diuretics, it helps prevent hypokalemia while maintaining Thiazide’s antihypertensive efficacy . This combination approach is particularly useful in patients experiencing thiazide-induced hypokalemia. Amiloride works as a weak antihypertensive but is valuable for its potassium-sparing properties, though it should be used cautiously in patients with renal failure or hyperkalemia. Classification of Diuretics : Type Mechanism of action Examples Clinical uses Side effects Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors Inhibit carbonic anhydrase enzyme in the proximal tubule, decreasing bicarbonate reabsorption Acetazolamide, Methazolamide Glaucoma, Altitude sickness Metabolic acidosis, Hypokalemia Loop diuretics Inhibit the Na-K-2Cl symporter in the thick ascending loop of Henle Furosemide, Bumetanide Acute pulmonary edema, Chronic heart failure, Hypercalcemia Hypokalemia, Ototoxicity, Metabolic alkalosis, Hyperglycemia, Hyperuricemia Thiazide diuretics Inhibit sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule Hydrochlorothiazide, Chlorthalidone Hypertension, Edema Hypokalemia, Hyponatremia, Hyperglycemia Hyperuricemia Potassium-sparing Inhibit sodium channels in the distal nephron or block aldosterone receptors Spironolactone, Amiloride Heart failure, Hyperaldosteronism Hyperkalemia, Gynecomastia (for Spironolactone) Osmotic diuretics Increase osmolarity of the glomerular filtrate, inhibiting water reabsorption. Mannitol, Glycerin Cerebral oedema, Acute glaucoma Dehydration, Electrolyte imbalance Furosemide (Option A): This is a loop diuretic that actually increases potassium excretion and can worsen hypokalemia. It is primarily used in patients with reduced GFR, CHF, or conditions requiring significant sodium excretion. Acetazolamide (Option C) : This carbonic anhydrase inhibitor is mainly used for treating glaucoma, altitude sickness, and periodic paralysis. It does not prevent potassium loss and can actually contribute to electrolyte imbalances. Indapamide (Option D) : This thiazide-like diuretic, similar to traditional thiazides, can cause potassium depletion and would not help prevent hypokalemia. It shares the same mechanism of action and side effect profile as other thiazide diuretics. Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page 562

questions.question: An 8-year-old child with a history of GTCS came with an episode of convulsions for more than 45 minutes. What will be the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Lorazepam followed by levetiracetam Explanation: Status epilepticus (SE) is defined as continuous seizures or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired consciousness lasting more than 30 minutes. They are generally of 2 types: Generalized convulsive status epilepticus (GCSE) GCSE is an emergency and must be treated immediately (e.g., persistent, generalized electrographic seizures, coma, and tonic-clonic movements). Nonconvulsive status epilepticus (NCSE) E.g., persistent absence seizures or focal seizures with confusion or partially impaired consciousness, and minimal motor abnormalities. In the case of impending and early SE, the standard protocol involves administering IV lorazepam 0.1 mg/kg followed by levetiracetam 20-30 mg/kg . For established and early refractory SE, the treatment progresses to Propofol 2 mg/kg IV followed by 2-10 mg/kg/hr with the addition of anticonvulsants like levetiracetam . Management of Status Epilepticus: Valproate followed by gabapentin (Option B) : While valproate can be used in the treatment of GTCS, this combination is not the standard first-line treatment for status epilepticus. Gabapentin is typically used for chronic seizure management rather than acute status epilepticus. Carbamazepine followed by lorazepam (Option C) : Carbamazepine is primarily used in the treatment of partial or focal seizures and is not appropriate for acute status epilepticus. Additionally, benzodiazepines should be administered first in status epilepticus, not after other anticonvulsants. Levetiracetam followed by valproate (Option D) : This sequence is incorrect as benzodiazepines (lorazepam) should be the first-line treatment in early status epilepticus.

questions.question: A 30-year-old male is admitted to the medicine ward with complaints of vomiting and diarrhea. Lab investigations reveal a serum potassium level of 3.2 mEq/L. All of the following can be signs of underlying dyselectrolytemia except:
questions.explanation: is related to fluctuations in the value of sodium (hyponatremia). Potassium does not play a role in plasma osmolality hence do not cause cerebral edema. Incorrect Options: Option A - Ventricular tachycardia: Hypokalemia can contribute to the development of Torsades de Pointes a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. Option B - Quadriplegia: Hypokalemia causes excessive hyperpolarization in skeletal muscles, impairing their ability to contract and leading to weakness and potential paralysis. Option C - Diabetes insipidus: Hypokalemic polyuria results from both excessive drinking (central polydipsia) and the kidneys' reduced response to antidiuretic hormone (AVP-resistant renal concentrating defect).

questions.question: Which of the following is the most likely condition responsible for a 35-year-old male experiencing nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting, with ABG results indicating pH of 7.55, PCO2 of 50 mmHg, and HCO3- of 44 mmol?
questions.explanation: direction, indicating a metabolic disorder, and with an increase in pH, the condition is likely metabolic alkalosis. Incorrect Options: Options A, B & C are correct.

questions.question: "Which of the following best characterizes the acid-base status of a 45-year-old diabetic patient presenting to the emergency department with abdominal pain, tachypnea, and tachycardia, whose arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following: pH: 7.34 Sodium (Na): 135 Potassium (K): 5 Bicarbonate (HCO3): 12 Chloride (Cl): 92 RBS = 450 mg/dl
questions.explanation: are reduced hence it indicates metabolic acidosis. Formula for Anion gap = [Na + ] - [Cl - + HCO 3 - ] In this scenario, Anion gap = 135 - [92 + 12] = 31 Therefore, the anion gap is >12 mEq/L which indicates a High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA). Incorrect Options: Options A, C & D are incorrect.

questions.question: A patient presented with complaints of pain in the flank region with hematuria. On investigation, an X-ray shows multiple calcifications (stones) in both kidneys. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Renal calculi The presence of flank pain, hematuria, and multiple calcifications seen on X-ray in both kidneys strongly suggests the presence of kidney stones. Clinical manifestations of Renal stones: Renal colic is typically characterised by severe, sharp, and fluctuating pain originating in the flank and radiating toward the lower abdomen or groin, based on the location of the stone within the ureter. Upper ureteral stone: Pain radiates anteriorly. Lower ureteral stone: Pain radiates to the ipsilateral groin or labium in females/testicles in males. Hematuria is a common finding due to ureteral irritation and damage caused by the sharp edges of the stone. Nausea and vomiting are frequently present due to the intensity of pain and reno-gastric reflex. Investigations for renal calculi Lab investigations: Urine analysis (24-hour urine analysis) and blood tests should be conducted to assess serum levels of calcium, uric acid, phosphate, oxalate, and other relevant substances. Radiological investigations: Helical CT abdomen (non-contrast) is the investigation of choice (gold standard) to confirm the diagnosis and locate the stones . Ultrasonography (abdomen, KUB) can also be done. X-ray (KUB) can also reveal radio-opaque stones such as Lysine, uric acid, and xanthine. Management of renal stones Medical management Surgical Management Analgesics like diclofenac, ketorolac, tramadol Fluid therapy: IVF (intravenous fluids) are administered to prevent dehydration Alpha 1 blocker: Tamsulosin (relaxes ureter and expels the stone). Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL): Indicated if the size of the calculi <2 cm . (Contraindicated in pregnancy and bleeding diathesis). PCNL (Percutaneous nephrolithotomy): If the size is >2 cm. Uretrorenoscopy Retrograde intrarenal surgery Pyelolithotomy and nephrolithotomy (rarely used). Parathyroid adenoma (Option A) refers to the enlargement of one or more of the parathyroid glands, which are responsible for regulating calcium levels in the body. While Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) (Option C) can lead to kidney-related symptoms, such as flank pain and hematuria, the presence of multiple calcifications (stones) in both kidneys is not a typical feature of this condition. While CKD (Option D) can lead to various complications, such as the formation of kidney stones, the presence of multiple calcifications (stones) in both kidneys on X-ray is not specific to CKD.

questions.question: A young patient developed hyperpigmentation of distal fingers after being hospitalized post-adrenalectomy. What could be the possible cause?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Nelson syndrome Nelson syndrome is a rare condition that occurs in patients who have had both adrenal glands removed (bilateral adrenalectomy) as a treatment for Cushing's disease. The hyperpigmentation of distal fingers post-adrenalectomy is due to the development of pituitary adenoma that produces excess adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), especially in areas exposed to friction and pressure, such as the distal fingers. Nelson syndrome/post-adrenalectomy syndrome Definition Nelson's syndrome is a condition that typically occurs after bilateral adrenalectomy for the treatment of Cushing's disease (pituitary-dependent Cushing’s syndrome). The removal of the adrenal glands leads to a lack of negative feedback on the pituitary, resulting in increased secretion of ACTH . Over time, the pituitary gland may develop a pituitary adenoma (or enlargement of an existing adenoma), which secretes ACTH in excess. Prevention Prophylactic radiation therapy may be indicated to prevent the development of Nelson’s syndrome after adrenalectomy Clinical features Hyperpigmentation Bitemporal hemianopia Progressive visual loss in cases of large tumours Headache Weakness and fatigue Inhibition of the release of other pituitary hormones Evaluation Fasting Plasma ACTH Levels: Very high levels. Diagnosis confirmed by an ACTH increase >30% of the initial result on three consecutive samples after bilateral adrenalectomy. Decreased levels of anterior pituitary hormones . Brain MRI shows pituitary tumours or enlargement of existing tumours. Screening: Regular screening with fasting plasma ACTH levels and brain MRI in patients after bilateral adrenalectomy. Management Surgical Removal of the Tumor Radiotherapy / Radiosurgery Medical Treatment Hormonal Replacement Therapy Addison's disease (Option A) involves primary adrenal insufficiency, where the adrenal glands do not produce sufficient steroid hormones. Hyperpigmentation can occur due to increased ACTH levels, but Addison's disease is typically associated with adrenal atrophy or autoimmune destruction, not post-adrenalectomy. Conn's syndrome (Option B) , or primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by excessive production of aldosterone by the adrenal glands. It does not typically cause hyperpigmentation. Symptoms are usually related to hypertension and hypokalemia. Cushing syndrome (Option D) is caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol. It usually leads to symptoms such as central obesity, moon face, and purple striae, rather than hyperpigmentation of the fingers. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 2916 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560755/

questions.question: 23 year old person with a history of flank Pain and fatigue and history of red coloured urine. On investigation there were more than 20 RBC/ hpf and microscopy showed dysmorphic RBC. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: red-colored urine, and the presence of more than 20 red blood cells (RBCs) per high-power field (hpf) with dysmorphic RBCs on microscopy, are indicative of glomerular involvement, which points toward a kidney-related issue. Among the options provided, PSGN is the most likely diagnosis for several reasons: Hematuria (Presence of RBCs in urine): The patient's history of red-colored urine and the presence of more than 20 RBCs/hpf in the urine sample indicate hematuria, which is a hallmark of glomerular pathology. Dysmorphic RBCs: Dysmorphic RBCs in the urine are a characteristic feature of glomerular bleeding. These abnormally shaped RBCs are a result of mechanical damage as they pass through the damaged glomerular capillaries. Flank Pain and Fatigue: Flank pain and fatigue can be associated with glomerulonephritis due to impaired kidney function and inflammation. History of Red-Colored Urine: The history of red-colored urine, also known as hematuria, further supports the presence of glomerular involvement. Incorrect Options: Option A - Minimal Change Disease: This is a form of nephrotic syndrome, characterized by massive proteinuria and minimal changes on light microscopy. It typically presents with proteinuria, edema, and normal to slightly elevated blood pressure. It doesn't usually cause gross hematuria or flank pain. Option C - UTI (Urinary Tract Infection): While a UTI can cause hematuria, it is less likely to cause dysmorphic RBCs and would not explain the flank pain and fatigue. Option D - Bladder Calculi: Bladder calculi (stones) might cause hematuria, but they would not explain the presence of dysmorphic RBCs, and typically, the pain associated with bladder stones is localized to the lower abdomen and not the flanks.

questions.question: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. On examination, the patient was hypotensive. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - IV Mannitol: The given scenario is suggestive of the dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS) or the reverse urea effect. Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS) is an acute neurological complication, often seen in patients undergoing their first hemodialysis session. It results from the rapid removal of urea and solutes, creating an osmotic gradient between the blood and brain interstitial fluid. This gradient causes water to shift into brain cells, leading to cerebral edema. Features: Symptoms: Headache, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, restlessness, confusion, muscle cramps, tremors, and in severe cases, seizures or coma. Risk Factors: First hemodialysis session, high blood urea nitrogen (BUN >175 mg/dL), children, elderly, rapid dialysis, and pre-existing neurological conditions. Management: Modify dialysis parameters to reduce urea removal rates. Administer osmotic agents like mannitol to reduce cerebral edema. Provide supportive care for symptoms. Prevention: Initiate dialysis at a slower rate with shorter sessions. Adjust dialysate composition, particularly sodium levels. Avoid aggressive uremia correction, especially in high-risk patients. Complications associated with Hemodialysis During treatment Between treatment Hypotension: The most common acute complication during hemodialysis , especially in patients with diabetes mellitus. Muscle cramps . Anaphylactoid reactions: These reactions, particularly to the dialyser, are most common during its first use and are often associated with bio incompatible cellulosic-containing membranes. Cardiac arrhythmias: D/t potassium & acid-base shifts. Hemorrhage: D/t anticoagulation & venous needle disconnection. Air embolism: D/t faulty lines & equipment malfunction. Pulmonary oedema (D/t fluid overload). Systemic sepsis: Usually involves vascular access devices (catheter or fistula). Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome typically occurs during or after a patient's first dialysis session. It presents with confusion, restlessness, headache, and muscle twitching. It is caused by a urea gradient between the CSF and blood that raises intracranial pressure. Amyloidosis ( D/t beta 2 microglobulin ) Carpal tunnel syndrome ( due to amyloid deposition in the flexor retinaculum). Peripheral neuropathy Bumetanide (Option A): Bumetanide is a loop diuretic used to treat conditions like fluid overload or edema, but it is not indicated for the management of dialysis disequilibrium syndrome. It works by inhibiting sodium and chloride reabsorption in the kidney, and does not address the osmotic shifts causing cerebral edema in DDS. Ethacrynic acid (Option B): Ethacrynic acid is another loop diuretic that can be used in conditions like edema, but it is not the first choice for treating DDS. It does not counteract the osmotic gradient responsible for cerebral edema during dialysis. Nesiritide (Option C): Nesiritide is a recombinant form of B-type natriuretic peptide, used to treat acute decompensated heart failure. It does not address the underlying pathophysiology of dialysis disequilibrium syndrome, which involves osmotic shifts causing cerebral edema.

questions.question: Which one of the following medications is not employed for the urgent (immediate) treatment of hyperkalemia?
questions.explanation: It may be used in certain situations, such as if the patient has concurrent magnesium deficiency, which can contribute to electrolyte imbalances. However, it is not the primary drug of choice for immediate intervention in hyperkalemia. Calcium gluconate (Option A) is commonly used in the emergency management of hyperkalaemia. It helps stabilise the cardiac membrane and counteracts the effects of elevated potassium levels on the heart. Salbutamol (Option B) , a beta-2 agonist, is frequently used for the immediate management of hyperkalaemia. It promotes the cellular uptake of potassium, effectively lowering its concentration in the blood. Insulin (Option C) , often administered with dextrose, is a key component of emergency hyperkalaemia management. Insulin drives potassium from the bloodstream into the cells, reducing serum potassium levels. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 352, 353, 354, 355

questions.question: All of the following aid in the localization of the lesion to the spinal cord except?

options.B: Fasciculation at the level of lesion
options.C: Upper motor neuron lesion and lower motor neuron lesion

questions.explanation: opposite to the side of the lesion. However, contralateral hemiplegia is not characteristic of lesions within the spinal cord . It is more commonly associated with brainstem lesions. Fasciculation at the level of the lesion (Option B) is observed at the uppermost level of the lesion in the spinal cord; it can provide clues about the involvement of the corresponding spinal cord segment. UMN lesions (Option C) involve the descending motor pathways (corticospinal) originating from the brain and traveling through the spinal cord , while LMN (Option C) lesions affect the peripheral nerves or nerve roots exiting the spinal cord . Bladder involvement (Option D), such as urinary retention or incontinence, can indicate dysfunction or damage to the nerves controlling bladder function within the spinal cord . Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 3446, 3429

questions.question: An increased anion gap is seen in:
questions.explanation: loss of bicarbonate (HCO 3 -) in the body, leading to a decrease in the bicarbonate concentration and a decrease in pH. This decrease is compensated by an increase in chloride ions, resulting in an increased anion gap. (Options A, B and D ruled out) Reference: Metabolic acidosis High anion gap Non-anion gap M ethanol poisoning U remia: AKI, CKD D iabetic ketoacidosis P aracetamol poisoning I ron and isoniazid L actic acidosis E thylene glycol poisoning S alicylate poisoning H yperchloremia A ddison's disease R enal tubular acidosis D iarrhoea and conditions causing GI loss of HCO3- (ureterosigmoidostomy or external bowel drainage) A cetazolamide S pironolactone and K-sparing diuretics S aline infusion (rapid infusion ) Reduced anion gap: Multiple myeloma and nephrotic syndrome
